There you have it: the fundamentals of Chess! You should by now know the rules, openings, basic tactics and a few advanced strategies. Now the only way to become even better is to play a lot, and maybe even analyse games a lot.

Playing games you can experiment with new ideas and learn how to play against all the different types of opponents you'll ever meet. Every game of Chess you can draw on your experience from previous ones. Maybe you recognize a situation and still know what move you made and whether it was the right one or not, or perhaps you have over time invented your own mating pattern that is very effective.

Analysing games you can learn from the mistakes other people, usually grandmasters, made in their games. Trying to come up with better alternatives will improve your skill. But, they also provide an opportunity for you to see new patterns and attacking combinations to use in your own games.

Anyhow, I will now give you some last tips and tricks that didn't really fit elsewhere, and then you be on your own!

  • On Sacrifices. A sacrifice is when you let the opponent capture one of your pieces without recapturing, to gain a positional advantage and maybe even a sure-fire way for a checkmate. However, don't think that sacrifices are magical unicorns that will always help your game. Only make a sacrifice if you are absolutely sure you are going to gain from it what you have in mind (or maybe even better). If you're not sure, you'll have sacrificed your piece for nothing 99% of the times.
  • For this reason: don't take an enemy piece without looking at the consequences. Maybe he made a bad move, maybe he's making a brilliant sacrifice.
  • Before moving a piece, see what it defends and what it prevents. Sometimes, one of your pieces is preventing an attack without you knowing it, and moving it will let your opponent loose. Also, make sure you don't provide the opponent with an opportunity to place a double attack. Always.
  • Develop knights before bishops. This is simply a logical insight: bishops are hidden behind a wall of pawns at the start of a game. Knights can get into the game and control the centre in one single move. It is therefore, most of the times, better to start with bringing your knights out.
  • Learn to think multiple moves ahead. If you only think one step ahead, your opponent won't have to go further either, and will always see through all your plans.
  • Learn to view the game from your opponent's POV. What does he want? Why does he do this particular move? What is he threatening? What does he think I want?
  • If you have finally achieved a winning position, don't let it slip away! Don't sit back and relax, don't start toying with your opponent---one wrong move and you have lost the game.
  • The first move disadvantage. Don't be the one starting an (equal) exchange, unless you can gain a great positional or tactical advantage from it. Let the opponent come---he will waste one move on starting the exchange. For example, say your opponent places his bishop in such a way that he is threatening your bishop. You could then use your move to exchange bishops, but that's probably what your opponent is hoping for. If your opponent wants to exchange anyway, let him do that in his own time and not yours.
" slug: "chess-general-tips-tricks" cat: "Miscellaneous" subcat: "Chess" video: "" diff: 3 quiz: "" - id: 127 title: "[Chess] Game Notation" post: "

In order to transcribe or analyse games, you have to know how to write down chess games in the correct form.

I am going to assume you are familiar with the several pieces, and the fact that the columns of the board are named a---g, and the rows are numbered 1---8.

The basic structure is like this:

> . > 1. d4 d5 2. Nc3 Nf6 3. …

Basically, every turn is seen as a pair of two moves---one from white and one from black. Because both players always alternate turns, this format can continue perfectly until the end of the game.

As you can see from the example, the most important part of notation is of course what square the piece is moved towards. But, we also want to know which piece is being moved. For that, an extra letter is added at the front:

> N for the knight, B for bishop, R for rook, Q for queen, K for king. Pawns have no letter in front. > Why the N for the knight? Because the K was already taken by the more important King. > Why nothing in front of the pawn? Because pawns are moved the most, and leaving out a prefix for these pieces speeds up the notation process considerably.

Furthermore, there are cases where for multiple pieces of the same type (e.g. two knights) could have moved to that square. In those cases, we also include the file of the starting square in front of the end square.

> Nde5 means the knight on the d file moved to e5, cd6 means the pawn from the c file moved to d6. > If both pieces are on the same file, we just include the whole square (Nd3e5).

And lastly, there are some symbols to clarify the state of the game:

  • An x in front of the target square means the piece captured something. (cxd6)
  • A + behind the target square means the opponent is in check after this move. (Ne5+)
  • A # behind the target square means the opponent is checkmated. (Qf6#)
  • O-O means the player castled kingside, O-O-O means castling queenside.

That's it!

Some extra notes: in game analysis, people often use an ! (e.g. Qf6!) to emphasize a move, meaning it was very important to the game, and a ? if they seriously question a player's move/decision. The combination of the two (!?) expresses that the person that analysed the game thought that move was absolutely bonkers.

" slug: "chess-game-notation" cat: "Miscellaneous" subcat: "Chess" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 128 title: "Guide to English Grammar" post: "

English is the language of the world. At the time of writing, English has 1500 million speakers worldwide, and it's growing rapidly as the first language of the world wide web. Learning the basics of the English language therefore enables you to communicate with nearly everyone all over the globe, whether you are writing a blog, giving presentations, or just want to explore other cultures. On top of that, learning a new language enhances your cognitive abilities.

This tutorial, however, is in English (as you might have noticed), which means you should already have at least some experience with reading English. Because of that, this guide is mainly focused on the grammar rules and principles, and gives few examples or exercises. It's certainly complete, but it doesn't even come close to an actual (college/high school) course or textbook. You should see this as something you read one time to iron out your grammar mistakes and learn the rules and their exceptions---and then use it as a reference when you're in doubt using English for something.

Anything concerning punctuation or quotes/dialogue doesn't belong here (in my opinion), and is discussed in the writing with style tutorial. I recommend you read that after you've explored this course---this course teaches you the fundamentals of the language, while the other one improves your writing with added elegance and fluency.

Last but not least: the English language has become famous for its (relatively) easy grammar, but expansive vocabulary. There are often lots of ways to say a certain thing, lots of synonyms for one concept, but only a few grammar rules (sometimes only a single rule) you need to know for every verb tense. That's why I think it is really important to study the grammar and remember it well, because it isn't much, but still gives you a complete understanding of the language. Vocabulary comes from a lot of reading, listening and writing.

With that out of the way: have fun with this course, and I hope you will find it useful!

Table of Contents

  1. Sentence Structure
  2. Nouns
  3. Pronouns
  4. Prepositions & Conjunctions
  5. Verbs I
  6. Verbs II
  7. Verbs III
  8. Verbs IV
  9. Adjectives
  10. Adverbs
  11. Determiners
  12. Cheat Sheet

" slug: "guide-english-grammar" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 1 quiz: "" - id: 129 title: "[English] Sentence Structure" post: "

A sentence is a meaningful set of words. A sentence is the smallest standalone piece of text that conveys meaning. To structure these words in such a way that anybody can understand exactly what they are trying to say, is called using grammar. Grammar takes to what group a word belongs (nouns, pronouns, adjectives, etcetera) and uses that to determine where and how it should be written. The first step to crafting beautiful sentences is knowing the structure every single one of them uses, and how simple or 'obvious' it may seem, I want to use some of your time to discuss it a little here.

Subject and Verb

These are the life of every line. The subject is what or who is doing something, and verb describes what action that person or thing is performing. In order for a sentence to work, it needs to contain at least some action. Something happening, some progress, some new event.

> The man eats

The man is the subject, the one doing something. What he does is eating, the verb. If you create a sentence and can't find the subject and/or verb, something went wrong.

Usually, the subject comes before the verb. They even appear together at the start of the sentence most of the times, but certainly not always.

Direct and Indirect Object

If you want to expand your sentence with more details, meaning or an extra twist, (in)direct objects are the first things you will want to add.

Direct Object: the person or thing receiving the action, the subject's 'victim'.

> The man eats the apple > The girl is watching a movie

Indirect Object: the person or thing participating in the action. The verb is not directly targeting it, but they tell for or to whom the direct object is meant. It describes the secondary goal of an action.

> The man gives the apple to the boy > The man gave his daughter a book (can be rewritten to the man gave a book to his daughter) > Let him have it

Relative and Subordinate Clauses

For even more complex or detailed sentences, you can add relative or subordinate clauses.

Relative Clauses: say something about the subject, providing details or specifics.

> The man, who visited me when I was sick, wears a hat

Subordinate Clauses: a small sub sentence---a sentence within a sentence. The subordinate clause adds a second action to the sentence, with its own subject and verb.

> The man eats the apple, while the girls eat chips.

Details and Modifiers

Of course there will be moments where you need to include more details to make a sentence clear. There are a few ways to achieve this:

  • Specifying nouns => The white cat is eating the red apple.
  • Modifying verbs => The woman stared intensely. The boy jumped wildly

Notice that by modifying verbs you basically answer the question how? - How did the subject perform the action? Intensely, wildly, gently, etcetera.

The other questions you could answer are the 5 W's and H: Who? What? When? Where? Why? How? For answering these you can use multiple techniques and constructions, which will all be discussed throughout the course.

> Peter hit frank => When did Peter hit Frank? => Yesterday, Peter hit Frank > The cat jumped => Where did the cat jump to? (What did the cat jump on?) => The cat jumped on the box

Conclusion

This course will start with explaining everything about nouns and verbs. This enables you to create all basic sentences, and creates a good base for you to build upon. Then all the ways to add details and modifiers are discussed.

" slug: "english-sentence-structure" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 1 quiz: "" - id: 130 title: "[English] Nouns" post: "

Nouns, together with verbs, are the basic building blocks of every language. In some languages, nouns take on different shapes and suffixes depending on their role or position within the sentence---but, luckily, not in English. Nouns stay almost exactly the same all the time, and there are only a few basic (and a few specific) rules I need to discuss here.

> Nouns give names to people, animals, places or things. > Examples: man, girl, apple, England, rabbit, house, March

Gender

In general, nouns don't have a gender. A dog doesn't have a specified gender, nor does a house or chair. Therefore, you usually don't have to worry about changing a noun based on gender. If you want to specify gender (for clarity), you can put male or female in front (a male friend, a female student).

There are some cases though, with people and animals, where you must use different words for different genders. A gender-neutral word---only to be used if the gender really doesn't matter or is unknown---is also sometimes available. Some of the more common ones are:

Masculine

Feminine

Neutral

Man

Woman

Person

Father

Mother

Parent

Waiter

Waitress

Server

Husband

Wife

Spouse

Boy

Girl

Child

When referring to an essentially gender-neutral noun used earlier in your story, it is always allowed to use it or they. But, if you want to express familiarity with the subject, you can actively assign a gender to the noun.

> This is my boat. I love it very much. > This is my boat. I love her very much.

Singular

If you refer to one specific noun, you use the in front of it.

> The man, the girl

If you refer to something or someone in a general way, you use a. If the noun starts with a vowel sound (phonetically, it starts with a vowel, excluding y), you use an to prevent creating a sentence that's impossible to pronounce.

> A man, an apple, a university, an honour

Plural

When you refer to a multiple of the noun, you omit any article and put the noun in plural form:

  • Plurals are formed by adding an ---s at the end: houses, cats, boys.
  • A singular noun ending in s, z, x, ch, sh needs the suffix ---es: wishes, foxes, buses.
  • If it ends in ---y, the y is replaced with ---ies: baby -> babies, city -> cities.

There's also a large list of irregular plurals in English, but the best way to remember these is reading a lot. Some important ones are included here:

Singular

Plural

Singular

Plural

Woman

Women

Man

Men

Child

Children

Tooth

Teeth

Foot

Feet

Person

People

Fish

Fish

Sheep

Sheep

Wife

Wives

Mouse

Mice

And lastly, a few nouns exist that are only used in plural form or acquire a different meaning when used as a singular noun. Examples are:

> His trousers are black > The news is always at 8 o'clock.

Countable & Uncountable

A very important and useful way to divide nouns into two groups: countable and uncountable.

Countable nouns can be counted. They have a singular and plural form, and you can put a number in front of them.

> Two dogs, five men, a child.

Uncountable nouns on the other hand have only one form---singular and plural at the same time. They are often abstract things or concepts. You can't put a number in front of them.

> Money, tea, bread, knowledge, love

Whether a noun is countable or not will be important especially later on when we look at adjectives and determiners.

Possessive

A noun can belong to someone or something. That's when you need to use the possessive form to show that relation. You can do that by putting 's (apostrophe s) behind the noun and before the thing it owns.

> John's car, France's army, men's clothes, Mark's patience.

If the noun ends in an ---s or ---x, you can show a possessive relationship by using an apostrophe only.

> Jess' smartphone, girls' room.

This is to prevent a lot of sss sounds after each other, but it is not required. Actually, the apostrophe can easily be missed on its own (by the reader), so it's recommended to not use this form.

Compound

English has a large vocabulary, but there are still cases where you need to combine two words to get the meaning you want. A lot of these compound nouns are very common and have found their way into the language as the way to say something, some of these are rarely seen or you can form yourself in case you need them.

Two words can be connected to each other, unless a problem could occur---the word could be read I the wrong way or mispronounced. In those cases, a space is added in between. If the word then can still be understood the wrong way, a hyphen is put between the two separate words.

> Police + man = policeman > Boy + friend = boyfriend > Water + tank = water tank > Washing + machine = washing machine > Train + spotting = train-spotting > Off + campus = off-campus

The rules however or not exact here, and you should consult a dictionary if you're not sure (or go with whatever sounds and looks best in your case).

Capitalization & Nationalities

A noun is capitalized (starts with an uppercase letter) if it is

  • The first word of the sentence
  • The first personal pronoun; I
    • I went to school today.
  • A month, day, season or holiday
    • The first day of March is a Monday.
  • A name or title. This includes names of streets, buildings, oceans, cities, regions, etcetera.
    • In California. The people of London. The water in the Atlantic. The Himalayas.
  • A language, nationality or adjective relating to nationality.
    • He lives in China. The French food was tasty. He speaks English. They are Japanese. Spaniards are handsome.

The names for countries, their language, and their corresponding adjective can differ a lot and are very irregular. You can say: in England live Englishmen, they speak English and drink English tea. But for another country this would become: in Spain live Spaniards, they speak Spanish and drink Spanish wine. Or: in Holland live Dutchmen, they speak Dutch and make Netherlandish art.

" slug: "english-nouns" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 1 quiz: "" - id: 131 title: "[English] Pronouns" post: "

Pronouns are actually more of a small subset of the large group of nouns, but because of their importance, and large amount of words you need to remember correctly, they deserve their own chapter. The type of pronoun you have to use depends on the noun it replaces (or 'refers to'), and the function that noun has within the sentence. They can therefore not always be used---but, if there's a possibility to use them instead of longer or more complicated nouns, that opportunity should always be seized.

> Pronouns replace nouns. They are shorter words, referring back to a noun used earlier in the sentence or paragraph. They avoid repetition and make sentences shorter and clearer. > Examples: Paul saw something in the dark, it was his shadow.

Subject

Object

Reflexive or intensive

Possessive

Possessive Adjective

Singular

1st person

I

me

myself

my

mine

2nd person

you

you

yourself

yours

your

3rd person male

he

him

himself

his

his

3rd person female

she

her

herself

hers

her

3rd person neutral

it

it

itself

its

Plural

1st person

we

us

ourselves

ours

our

2nd person

you

you

yourselves

yours

your

3rd person

they

them

themselves

theirs

their

Subject Pronouns

You use this pronoun if it is the subject of the sentence:

> You eat an apple. I like that.

Object Pronouns

You use this form if it is the (direct or indirect) object of the sentence:

> He sent the letter to me. The man eats the apple for them.

Reflexive & Intensive Pronouns

Reflexive and intensive pronouns are the same words, but fulfil different functions in a sentence.

Reflexive pronouns are used if the object is the same person or thing as the subject. You're reflecting on something you did to yourself.

> She hit herself with a tennis racket. We blame ourselves for the failure.

Intensive pronouns are used if you want to intensify the subject of the sentence. They stress the importance of the subject, but can be removed or left out without changing the meaning of the sentence.

> I baked these cakes myself. They themselves told me what I did was fine.

Possessive Pronouns

These pronouns provide an alternative for showing a possessive relationship between two nouns. We've already seen that you can use an---'s (Jack's house). This pronoun can remove the need to mention Jack again if he is the one talking or he has been mentioned earlier.

> Jack was a nice guy. This house was his. > This candy is mine.

Possessive Adjectives

They are special: they don't really replace a noun like all pronouns do, but they are very closely related to them. They provide a third alternative for showing a possessive relation: this time, we are putting an adjective, referring to the owner, in front of the noun.

> The dog broke its leg. They went to their school. I can't find my shoes.

Indefinite pronouns

Indefinite pronouns replace a specific or countable noun for one that is vague, broad or uncountable. They can replace a person, thing or place. They can either refer to all of them, an undefined part of them, or none of them. Which one you should use depends on the type of sentence---affirmative or negative.

Person

Thing

Place

All

everyone

everybody

everything

everywhere

Part (affirmative)

someone

somebody

something

somewhere

Part (negative)

anyone

anybody

anything

anywhere

None

no one

nobody

nothing

nowhere

Affirmative

Affirmative sentences are when something is true (or at least expected to be true). When something is happening, someone is present, etcetera.

> Everybody aced that test. Nobody is sleeping at the moment. I looked everywhere for that book. He thinks it must be somewhere around here.

The indefinite pronouns belonging to negative sentences can only be used affirmatively, if they are close to every in their meaning. You should be able to replace 'any' with 'every' in those sentences without changing the meaning.

> You may invite anyone. She would give anything for that opportunity.

Negative

Negative sentences are when something is not true (or you don't expect it to be). It's not happening, not working, not available, not possible.

> He doesn't have anything to eat. She hasn't gone anywhere the past few months. He couldn't find anybody to work with.

Questions

Usually when we ask a question, we are really not sure about the answer, and therefore use any (or every) in almost all questions. The only exceptions are when you already know or highly suspect the answer.

> Did you eat anything yesterday? Did you see anyone when you were there? (we are really curious) > Have you lost something? Are you looking for someone? (we've already seen that someone is searching for something or someone)

We can also negate the sentence---adding or removing the word not in the sentence---if we expect a certain yes or no answer.

> Didn't you eat anything yesterday? (we expect a no) > Haven't you lost something? (we expect a yes) " slug: "english-pronouns" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 132 title: "[English] Prepositions & Conjunctions" post: "

These two types of words are absolutely crucial to most sentences, but often go unnoticed. You should see this chapter more as a reference for later---don't bother trying to remember all of these if you haven't learnt the more important building blocks of grammar yet. If you find a word in this course you don't understand, you could come here and check it.

> Prepositions are short words connecting verb and object. > Examples: on, after, in, at, for, behind, past, to, through > Conjunctions are short words connecting (parts of) sentences. > Examples: and, but, however, nevertheless

Prepositions

A lot of verbs require a specific preposition, or change meaning based on different prepositions belonging to it. There's no rule for this: you learn this from reading proper English a lot. Even native speakers get this wrong sometimes or just don't know the correct form.

A preposition is anything you can put before the noun the closet or the party in a sentence.

> For example; to the party, after the party, at the party, about the party, etcetera

Always check if you're using the correct preposition, or your sentence might be completely wrong or attain some other (awkward) meaning.

Conjunctions

There are 4 types of conjunctions, and I want to show all of them to you here. Not because you will use all of them all the time, but because you need to recognize them and using them will add structure and variation to all your stories.

Coordinating Conjunctions

Used to join individual words, phrases and independent clauses (a clause that could be a sentence on its own). Usually placed in the middle of a sentence, and with a comma before it. They are:

> And, but, or, nor, yet, so, for > Should Me and Mike go fishing or go swimming? She was sad, for her cat just died.
Subordinating Conjunctions

Introduce dependant clauses. Usually placed at the front of the clause, and with a comma at the end of that clause. There's a lot of them:

Concession

Time

Relative Adjective

though

although

even though

while

after

as long as

as soon as

before

by the time

now that

once

since

till

until

when

whenever

while

that

what

whatever

which

whichever

Condition

if

only if

unless

until

provided that

assuming that

even if

in case (that)

lest

Relative Pronoun

who

whoever

whom

whomever

whose

Comparison

Reason

Manner

than

rather than

whether

as much as

whereas

because

since

so that

in order (that)

why

how

as though

as if

Place

where

wherever

Don't worry: the most important ones will be discussed and explained later in this course.

Correlative Conjunctions

Come in pairs, and denote equality; they show the relationship between ideas expressed in different parts of the sentence.

as … as

just as … so

both … and

hardly … when

scarcely … when

either … or

neither … or

if … then

not … but

what with … and

whether … or

not only … but also

no sooner … than

rather … than

Conjunctive Adverbs

Used to link two ideas, and are basically variations on and, but and so.

Similar to And

Similar to But

Similar to So

also

besides

furthermore

likewise

moreover

however

nevertheless

nonetheless

still

conversely

instead

otherwise

rather

accordingly

consequently

hence

meanwhile

then

therefore

thus
" slug: "english-prepositions-conjunctions" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 133 title: "[English] Verbs I" post: "

Now that you know everything about nouns, we can start introducing verbs and all their tenses and variations. There are quite a lot of them, but they mostly look alike. The issue therefore is more that you might mix them up and use the wrong tense, than that you could forget how they work or should be formed.

> Verbs describe action > Examples: to run, to walk, to swim, to eat

Conjugations

There are only a few conjugations for every verb.

  • Infinitive: the way you'll find words in the dictionary. The full, abstract version of the verb.
    • To think, to see, to eat, to know, to hear
  • Regular: this is the infinitive without 'to'. Mostly used in the simple present and simple future tense.
    • I think, you see, we eat, you know, I hear
  • Third-person singular regular: The third-person singular forms of the regular type, need something extra: an ---s at the end. Verbs ending in an ---y (without a vowel in front of the y) are formed by replacing it with ---ies. Verbs ending in---ss, -x , -sh, -ch need an ---es at the end.
    • He thinks, she sees, it eats.
    • To fly => he flies. To cry => she cries
    • He catches, she fixes, it scratches.
  • Past (participle): if a verb is regular, the past is formed by adding ---ed after the regular form. If the verb already ends in an -e, only a ---d is added. If a verb is irregular, anything could happen really. Irregular verbs also sometimes have another different form for the past participle.
    • I laughed, they jumped, we landed, you hated.
    • I think => I thought. You see => you saw. We eat => we ate.
  • Continuous: this form is used when we want to stress something is happening at the time the sentence is written in. For example, we can say that five hundred years ago a certain event was happening. Or that in two days something else will be happening. As you can see, they are simply formed by adding ---ing at the end of a verb. They are nice, because they are very regular.
    • Thinking, seeing, eating, knowing, hearing.

How can you form all those tenses with only this? As you will see, auxiliary verbs are often added.

Auxiliary Verbs

These are helping verbs. They can stand on their own, but they are most commonly seen supporting other verbs to create certain tenses. They are quite irregular, but very important to learn:

to be

to do

to have

regular

past

regular

past

regular

past

I

am

was

do

did

have

had

You

are

were

do

did

have

had

He/she/it

is

was

does

did

has

had

We

are

were

do

did

have

had

You

are

were

do

did

have

had

They

are

were

do

did

have

had

Past participle

been

done

had

Modal Verbs

Modal verbs are special types of auxiliary verbs. They show an obligation, possibility or necessity. These can't really stand on their own, and always support the actual main verb. They only have a single form that never changes. All modal verbs are:

can

you have the ability to do something

could

you had the ability sometime in the past

may

you are allowed to do something, or will maybe do it

might

you are maybe allowed to something, or could perhaps do it

must

you are obliged to do something, or it is highly likely it will happen

ought

executing the action is the right thing to do, or it is fairly likely/expected to happen

should

 > you strongly advice or insist on doing something

would

if you had the possibility/opportunity, you had done it.

Examples: You should say yes. I know I would. You can always put it off a few weeks, but you ought to at least tell them you're in doubt. You may be able to say no, but it might turn out worse. You must make a decision now!

Contractions & Negations

All auxiliary and some modal verbs are used very often, and therefore have a special contraction when they are combined with the word not.

to be

to do

to have

regular

past

regular

past

regular

past

I

aren't

(ain't)

wasn't

don't

didn't

haven't

hadn't

Regular

aren't

weren't

don't

didn't

haven't

hadn't

He/she/it

isn't

wasn't

doesn't

didn't

hasn't

hadn't

The modal verbs can, could, must, should and would have their contraction formed by just adding the ---n't at the end.

> You shouldn't do that. I wasn't ready for this. He just wouldn't tell what happened.

As you can see, if you want to negate a sentence or statement you replace an auxiliary verb by its contraction. If no auxiliary verb is present, you add a contraction of the verb to do.

> I like to walk home => I don't like to walk home (regular) > I walked home yesterday => I didn't walk home yesterday (past)

The Modal Verb 'will'

This is a bit of a special one. The word will always indicates an action will take place in the future, and has a large number of meanings and functions (as you will see in the next chapter).

For all people, the word is always written as will. I will, you will, they will, etcetera. The negation contraction is always won't. If the subject is I or we you can use shall and shan't instead, but those are not popular anymore in modern English.

Contractions for Brevity

Because of their numerous appearances in English, auxiliary verbs can also contract with the subject if the sentence is affirmative (not negative).

to be

to have

had

will

would

I

I'm

I've

I'd

I'll

I'd

You

You're

You've

You'd

You'll

You'd

He

He's

He's

He'd

He'll

He'd

She

She's

She's

She'd

She'll

She'd

It

It's

It's

It'd

It'll

It'd

We

We're

We've

We'd

We'll

We'd

They

They're

They've

They'd

They'll

They'd

There

There's

There's

There'd

There'll

There'd

That

That's

That'd

That'll

That'd

Examples: I'm Frank. I've always been Frank. When I was young, I'd always go fishing in France. We'd never thought of moving there though.

Questions

Questions in English are formed by switching around the subject and auxiliary/modal verb.

> You have seen the news => Have you seen the news? > He should have done that => Should he have done that?

If no auxiliary/modal verb exists, a form of to do is added to the sentence at the beginning.

> I walk down the road => Do I walk down the road? > They see the chicken => Do they see the chicken?

Answering a question can then be done by using the same auxiliary verb used within the question, using a contraction if the answer is negative.

> Have you seen the news? Yes I have! > Do you walk down the road? No, I don't.

Using contractions/negations to change question meaning or intention is already discussed in the pronouns chapter.

Knowing all this, we can continue with the actual verb tenses. Do keep in mind that English has a lot of tenses that seem very similar to one in your own language, but are essentially different.

" slug: "english-verbs-part-one" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 134 title: "[English] Verbs II" post: "

Instead of grouping verbs by past, present and future, I like to use a different approach here. In English, other types of tenses like the perfect tense or conditional tenses are used much more often, and are perhaps an even more essential part of the language than some of the past/present/future tenses. There's also a significant distinction to be made between tenses that look exactly the same, and that's why I will try to work a little differently by grouping the types of tenses instead of their timing.

Simple Tenses

The simple tense is called that way because it is the simplest of them all when it comes to grammar. When it comes to meaning though, every time has some specific and significant differences that you should know and understand. The simple tense doesn't describe actions as they are happening, but rather general truths, appointments, repeated actions/habits, instructions, etcetera. For example, this tutorial is almost entirely written in the present simple, because they are all general truths and instructions on how to use English.

Simple Present

The simple present is constructed by using the regular form, and the third-person singular form if the subject is a he/she/it.

> I work in Manchester. The exam starts at 10 AM. I'll address this issue after I come home.

It's used for:

  • Habits, general truths, repeated actions and unchanging situations, emotions, or wishes.
  • Giving instructions or directions
  • Expressing fixed arrangements/appointments in the present or future.
  • Expressing a future time, only after the conjunctions after, before, as soon as, until, when.
Simple Past

The simple past is constructed by using the past form only.

> Her mother died last year. We lived in Canada in 1985. They talked about it yesterday.

It's used for:

  • Something that happened frequently in the past (she often walked home alone)
  • A definite point in time (They made the arrangements last week)
  • An indefinite point in time (We decided against it long ago)

NOTE: If you have a negative sentence, which means adding didn't to the sentence, the verb must be in regular form. The auxiliary verb didn't is already in past form.

> Her father didn't die last year. We didn't live in Canada in 1985.
Simple Future

The simple future is constructed by using the auxiliary verb will + regular form.

> He'll never agree. Will you marry me? It will rain tomorrow.

It's used to:

  • Predict a future event.
  • Express a spontaneous decision (with I or we).
  • Express willingness. Express unwillingness when negated.
  • Make an offer, suggest something or ask for advice/instructions (you must use shall then).
  • Give orders, when addressing someone or a group directly (with you).
  • Give an invitation, with you in interrogative form (a question).

Continuous Tenses

The continuous tense describes an action that is happening at the moment of speaking/writing. It describes something that started earlier and is still continuing. In contrast to the simple tense, this is a snapshot of an action happening somewhere in time.

Continuous Present

The continuous present is constructed by using a regular form of to be + continuous form.

> We are walking. They are talking. I am waiting. You are learning.

Again, to negate the sentence you use a contraction of the to be verb (aren't/isn't).

It's used to:

  • Describe an action that is going on at this moment.
  • Describe an action that is going on during a (current) period of time, like a trend or ongoing project (I'm still working on this website of mine)
  • Describe an action or event in the future which is already planned and prepared (I'm meeting with my girlfriend tomorrow)
  • Describe a temporary event or situation---something special that is currently going on (It's raining now, but the sun should reveal herself any time)
  • Describe an ongoing series of repeating actions---with always, forever or constantly in front (You two are always arguing!)
Continuous Past

The continuous past is constructed by using a past form of to be + continuous form.

> We were walking. They were talking. I was waiting. You were learning.

It's used to describe actions before now, which began in the past and are still going on or interrupted/unfinished. Usually this is used to describe what was happening while some main event occurred:

> The birds were singing and the trees were swinging as the lion woke up.

It's also used, in combination with to wonder, to make a very polite request:

> I was wondering if you would like to go to the ball with me.
Continuous Future

The continuous future is constructed by using 'will be' + continuous form.

> She will be sleeping over next Monday. They will be dancing at the party next week.

It's used to describe actions that will be in progress at some time in the future. This can be a completely new action (I will be learning English tomorrow) or one that has already been started but isn't finished yet (I will still be learning English tomorrow). The latter must always be combined with still.

Other uses are:

  • Predicting or guessing future events (I think we will be having a hard time tomorrow)
  • Asking politely for information about the future (Will you be working on the assignment tomorrow?)
  • Referring to events we expect to happen ( = be ongoing) in the future. (Tomorrow it will be raining cats and dogs)

For negative sentences, you can use won't be + continuous form.

" slug: "english-verbs-part-two" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 135 title: "[English] Verbs III" post: "

This is where the real fun begins. Up until now we've only seen the basic building blocks of English (well, of any language really). You could write articles and novels with only those tenses, but that would quickly become a very monotone story. That's where the perfect tense and some more fancy stuff kicks in.

Perfect Tenses

Perfect tenses is where the different time spans and simple/continuous begin to overlap and mix. There are therefore 6 variations on it, all equally important. So let's start.

Simple Present Perfect

The simple present perfect is constructed by using a regular form of to have + past participle.

> I have lived here all my life. They have been to the zoo twice this week. We have been to the zoo several times. She has just finished reading the book. He has read the Hobbit thrice.

It's used for:

  • An action/situation that started in the past and still continues in the present.
  • An action performed during a period that has not yet finished.
  • A repeated action in an unspecified period between the past and the present.
  • An action that was completed in very recent past, expressed with just.
  • An action when the time is not important, but the result.
Continuous Present Perfect

The continuous present perfect is constructed by using a regular form of to have + 'been' + continuous form.

> I have been cycling to school every day for years. They have been kissing for an hour now.

It's used for actions that started an unspecified time before now and are still going on in the present.

> She has been waiting for him all day (…when exactly did she start waiting? We don't know)

It can also be used for actions that have just finished, and we are interested in the results.

> It's been raining since last night (...which means the streets are still wet)
Simple Past Perfect

The simple past perfect is constructed by using a past form of to have + past participle.

> Mark had already left when I arrived. She had just saved the document when the computer crashed.

If the present perfect is about actions starting before now and going on until the present, the past goes back even further---it's about actions starting earlier than before now. Because the whole sentence is in the past, the simple past perfect is mostly about making clear that one event happened before another (in the past).

Continuous Past Perfect

The continuous past perfect is constructed by using a past form of to have + 'been' + continuous form.

> We had been trying to contact him, but we were unable to reach him.

Again, it describes a process that was happening in a time earlier than before now. The example sentence could be rewritten to:

> We were unable to reach him (they concluded they failed to reach him in a time before now), after we had been trying to contact him (and even earlier, they already tried contacting him)

This tense can also be used in reported speech. Basically, if someone says something about the past, and you want to say something about that quote, you use it.

> "I have been working in my office all day," Mark told the police. > Mark told the police that he had been working in his office all day.
Simple Future Perfect

The simple future perfect is constructed by using 'will have' + past participle.

> Soon, they will have arrived at the building. By the time you read this, I will have left this world.

They refer to a point in the future where an action is completed. We are basically placing ourselves in the future, and we see that a certain action will then be done or finished.

Continuous Future Perfect

The continuous future perfect is constructed by using 'will have been' + continuous form.

> By 2016, I will have been living in Manchester for five years.

Because this is the continuous tense, we are again referring to an action to is still going on at a certain point in future time.

> Next week (some point in the future), I will have been living with Sarah for two years (you've completed two years of living with Sarah, but you haven't stopped living with her).

Passive Voice

The passive voice is used when we want to place emphasis on the object, the 'victim' of the action, or we're just not interested in the subject. Usually though, using active language (which is everything we've discussed until now) is better, shorter and clearer---so try to use that whenever you can. Nevertheless, it's still important to know the passive voice, especially because it looks like a simple or continuous present tense, but means something entirely different.

> (active) Alan Parsons wrote "Old & Wise" => "Old & Wise" was written by Alan Parsons (passive)

The passive voice is constructed by a conjugated form of to be + past participle. It's a combination between the simple and continuous tenses, and the past participle from the perfect tense.

to be (conjugated)

past participle

Simple present

The car…

is

cleaned

Present continuous

is being

cleaned

Simple Past

was

cleaned

Past Continuous

was being

cleaned

Simple future

will be

cleaned

Future continuous

will be being

cleaned

Present perfect

has been

cleaned

Past perfect

had been

cleaned

Notice that in all sentences we don't know who is, was or will be cleaning the car, we only know that the car is being cleaned.

The most prominent use of passive voice is with the fact that being born is something passive.

> I was born in 1997. Where were you born?

The so-called infinitive passive voice is used after modal verbs or other verbs requiring an infinitive, and is constructed by using '(to) be' + past participle.

> You have to be tested on your writing skills. He wants to be invited to the party. She may be disappointed in you.

The gerund passive voice is used after verbs that require gerunds behind it on all other occasions, and is constructed by using 'being' + past participle.

> I hate interviewing => I hate being interviewed > My dogs like cuddling => My dogs like being cuddled

Those infinitives and gerunds (and conditionals) are all discussed thoroughly in the next chapter!

" slug: "english-verbs-part-three" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 3 quiz: "" - id: 136 title: "[English] Verbs IV" post: "

This last chapter on verbs will discuss the more fancy, complex or detailed types of sentences you'll run into. Some of them occur sparingly or almost solely in written English, but it's still important to see all that is possible.

Conditional tenses

Until now we've only seen sentences that describe something that did or did not happen. Conditional tenses are used when there's a possibility of some event happening in the past, present or future, but only under a certain condition. Every one of these conditionals can be put in a different order without changing meaning, although that may require adding some extra determiners.

Future Conditional

The future conditional uses the construction:

> If X happens, Y will happen. > If he is late again, I will be very angry.

The first part uses the simple present, while the second part uses the simple future.

Present (Zero) Conditional

The present conditional uses the construction:

If X happens, Y happens.

If water cools down, it freezes.

Both parts use the simple present. It's often called a zero conditional, because it doesn't really involve a condition: Y is the natural consequence of X and will always follow immediately.

Past Conditional

The past conditional uses the construction:

> If X happened, Y would be happening. > If he was a better soccer player, he would be scoring goals now.

Both parts of the conditional are false: he isn't scoring goals now, which means he's not as good of a soccer player. But on the condition that he was a better player, he would be scoring now.

Past Perfect Conditional

The past perfect conditional uses the construction:

If X had happened, Y would have happened

If Mark had had more time, he would have visited his grandparents.

Again, both parts are false and the chance to change it lies in the past, but this time we're in that earlier than before now state. If Mark had had more time in the past, he would by now already have completed his quest of visiting his grandparents.

Mixed Conditional

Mixed conditionals mix several of the previously discussed types. There's basically two types:

Present result of past condition: If X had happened (in the past), Y would happen (now).

> If I had studied, I would have my high school diploma.

Past result of present (or continuing) condition: If X happened (just now), Y would have happened (in the past).

> If I wasn't afraid of failure, I would have sang the song in front of a large crowd.

Gerund & Present Participle

The Gerund and Present Participle in theory mean nothing else than the continuous form of a verb we've been using all along. But, they portray two different functions.

Gerund

It always has the function of a noun, even though it looks like a verb.

It can stand on its own as the subject of a sentence: Hunting is bad for the environment. In all other cases, it functions as part of a noun and needs other words around it.

It must be used after:

  • A preposition: We arrived after driving for two hours
  • A phrasal verb (verb made from more than one word): He has been trying to give up smoking.
  • The expressions can't help, can't stand, to be worth and it's no use: It's no use trying to escape.

A last possible use is as a complement of the verb to be:

His life goal is to find all Pokémon => His life goal is finding all Pokémon

Present Participle

In contrast to the gerund, the present participle actually has the expected function of a verb. It is used in the continuous tenses, but has many other uses.

  • After verbs of movement and position, for example: to go, to come, to lay, to sit.
    • They went hiking. She lay looking at the stars. I came running towards him. We sat staring out of the window.
  • After verbs of perception, for example: to hear, to see, to smell, to watch, to feel.
    • I felt the wind blowing in my face. I heard someone singing down the street.
  • With the verbs spend and waste: the construction is verb + time/money expression + present participle.
    • The doctor spends five hours a day sleeping. I wasted a hundred dollars trying to get there.
  • With the verbs catch and find: the construction is verb + object + present participle.
    • I caught him stealing my wallet. They found two old coins lying in the sand.
  • Describing two actions at the same time: the construction is usually present participle + actual action.
    • Singing to herself, she cycled to school. 'Hands behind your head,' he said, pulling his gun.

Infinitives

Infinitives have many different uses and specific constructions they appear in. To keep things organized, I will introduce two different types of infinitives:

  • The regular infinitive: to + base verb (to remember)
  • The zero infinitive: base verb (remember)

To negate the infinitive you simply put the word not in front, as this can always be done in this case.

Regular Infinitive

It can be used:

  • To indicate the purpose or intention of an action. In that case, the word to could be replaced with in order to or so as to.
    • She came to school to receive her award.
  • As the subject of a sentence. This makes sentences needlessly complicated, so is most often seen in written works of art.
    • To find true love is the purpose of life! To be or not to be.
  • To indicate what something can or will be used for.
    • They will need some space to work in. Would you like a slice of cake to eat?
  • After adjectives. The construction is:
    • Subject + to be + adjective ( + for/of someone) + regular infinitive ( + rest of sentence).
    • He is interesting for you to talk to. She is a nice girl to flirt with.
  • To make a comment or judgment. The construction is:
    • Subject + to be + noun phrase + regular infinitive.
    • They are a dangerous group to run into late at night. Jim is the worst person to ask for these kind of matters.
  • With adverbs too and enough.
    • She is too beautiful to flirt with. There is enough food to feed everyone here.
  • With question words. The verbs ask, decide, explain, forget, know, show, tell and understand can be followed by a question word + regular infinitive.
    • Do you know how to draw a cat? Has he explained when it's best to mow the lawn? No, but I've been show how to draw a dog instead.
Zero Infinitive

Luckily, the zero infinitive has far less uses. These are:

  • After auxiliaries.
    • He can't explain that to you now. Would she tell you if she knew?
  • After verbs of perception. The construction is:
    • Verb + object + zero infinitive
    • They heard her scream. We watched him try to get on his bike.
  • After the verbs make and let.
    • Let's go! You made him do that.'
  • After the expression had better.
    • She had better go to bed now. You'd better give me some more time!
  • In combination with why, making a suggestion.
    • Why wait until he returns? Why not sleep at Jim's place?

" slug: "english-verbs-part-four" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 4 quiz: "" - id: 137 title: "[English] Adjectives" post: "

Adjectives help nouns. They always apply to one or several noun(s), and attempt to enrich their target by adding more information or detailing. You could say Two girls are walking down the street. One girl finds a wallet. But then we'd all be wondering: which one of them? Adding an adjective clears things up: A short and tall girl are walking down the street together. The tall one finds a wallet. As you can see, adjectives add more detail and information, but also increase sentence length and complexity. You should therefore not stuff every sentence with adjectives---only use them when they are actually useful or necessary. In some cases, you can find a single noun to replace adjective + noun.

> Adjectives modify or describe nouns > Examples: red, boring, beautiful, tall, short, nice, friendly, inviting, green

Placement of Adjectives

There are two ways to place adjectives:

  • Immediately in front of the noun: Yesterday, I've placed a small table in my big house.
  • After being or sensing verbs: My house is big. The table seems small.

Adjectives don't change their form based on the gender or number (singular/plural) of the noun they belong to---they always stay the same.

NOTE: To intensify adjectives, you can use the word very or really in front of them. Those are actually adverbs, and will be discussed in the next chapter. But, sometimes an intensified version of the noun is already available in the dictionary, and it is advised to use that.

NOTE 2: The adjectives involved, present and concerned can appear behind the noun, but that changes their meaning.

Comparing with Adjectives

There are a few different structures to use when comparing equal and unequal nouns:

  • Equal; as + adjective + as
    • Jack is as tall as Jim
  • Unequal; not as + adjective + as
    • Jack is not as tall as Jim
  • Unequal; less + adjective + than
    • Jack is less tall than Jim
  • Unequal; comparative adjective + than
    • Jack is taller than Jim
  • One clear winner of the comparison; the + superlative adjective
    • Jack is the tallest of the two.

How to form the comparative and superlative adjective will be discussed next section.

Comparative & Superlative

It depends on the amount of syllables in a word how the comparative and superlative are formed.

  • One Syllable. Add ---er for comparative and ---est for superlative. If the adjective ends with the pattern single vowel + consonant, you need to double the consonant.
    • Tall => Taller => Tallest
    • Sad => Sadder => Saddest
  • Two Syllables. Not all of these can be formed in the way described above, and are formed by using more + adjective for comparative and most + adjective for superlative. If you are not sure, you can always play safe and use that system. Adjectives ending in ---y need to replace it with an ---i.
    • Happy => Happier => Happiest
    • Tilted => More tilted => Most titled
  • Three or More Syllables. These adjectives always follow the most and more pattern.
    • Important => More important => Most important
    • Beautiful => More beautiful => Most beautiful

The most important comparative adjectives are irregular, and you will have to just memorize the following table.

Normal Adjective

Comparative

Superlative

good

better

best

bad

worse

worst

little

less

least

much

more

most

far

further / farther

furthest / farthest

Quantities

Right at the start of this course, we talked about countable and uncountable nouns. If you want to compare quantities, there are different words you should use.

A = B

A = B

A > B

A < B

Countable

many

few

more

fewer

Uncountable

much

little

more

less

What's the difference between the first two columns? The first describes two equal nouns that are in numerous quantities. The second describes two equal nouns that are scarce.

> It seems as if there are as many children on the playground as there are ants in the world. (there were a lot of children there) > We had little money (they didn't have a lot of money). > He had even less patience than Jim. > They had fewer points than the other team.

Multiple Adjectives

There is no fixed order you must follow when using multiple adjectives in a row, but there is a sort of generally accepted order you should use most of the time, which is:

Quantity => Value/Opinion => Size => Temperature => Age => Shape => Colour => Origin => Material

Examples: The two beautiful birds. The large, cold ice cream. The two ten year olds. The rectangular, green box. The awesome metal car.

" slug: "english-adjectives" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 2 quiz: "" - id: 138 title: "[English] Adverbs" post: "

Adverbs are the wildcard of any language. They can be formed out of anything, and applied to nearly everything. The subject and object in a sentence (nouns + adjectives) answers the question Who? The verb answers the question What? Relative clauses usually answer the question Why?

Adverbs try to answer the remaining questions: When? Where? and How?

> Adverbs modify a verb, adjective or other adverb. > Examples: The lived happily ever after. He angrily threw the baseball. The test went very well.

You can find adverbs by rephrasing a sentence in interrogative form:

> Mark just loudly sang the beautifully composed song there. > How did Mark sing? Loudly > How was the song composed? Beautifully > When did Mark sing? Just (not so long ago) > Where did Mark sing? There

As you can see, adverbs are everywhere, but rarely stand on their own in a sentence. If they modify a verb, they are usually placed after it. If the modify an adjective, they are placed in front of it.

Forming Adverbs

In most cases, they are formed by adding ---ly behind their adjective.

> Quick => Quickly.

Again, if the adjective ends in an ---y, replace it with an ---i.

> Easy => Easily.

If the adjective ends in ---able,---ible or---le, replace the ---e with an ---i.

> Terrible => Terribly.

If the adjective ends in ---ic, add ---ally at the end.

> Basic => Basically. > One exception: public => publicly.

Some common adjectives have the same form as adverbs, which are:

> Early, fast, hard, high, late, near, straight and wrong > She always drives very fast.

And one very important thing to remember, is that the adverb of good is well.

> She is a good soccer player => She plays well.

Comparative and Superlative Adverb

Because adverbs end in ---ly, you could form the comparative and superlative with ---ier and ---iest. But, the most common (and better) approach is to just place more and most in front.

> Slowly => More slowly => Most slowly

Very short adverbs that do not end in---ly (especially the ones that didn't change), are formed in the usual way:

> Fast => Faster => Fastest

Relative Adverbs

You can always use the structure (in/at/on/for) + which to connect a relative clause to the sentence.

> There was a rain storm going on the week in which she was born

But, you can make the sentence shorter and clearer by using relative adverbs (where, when or why) instead:

> There was a rain storm going on the week when she was born

Interrogative Adverbs

We've been talking about who, what, where, when, why and how the whole time, and now we can give them a name: interrogative adverbs.

You can place them at the beginning of a sentence, and if you don't forget to switch around the subject and verb, you have a question:

> How often do you shave? > Where did he suddenly come from? > What time is it?

The word how has only four specific uses:

  • When it means in what way.
    • How do you repair a bike?
  • To ask about the degree of an attribute (/adjective)
    • How old do you think he is?
  • In combination with other adverbs, to ask about frequency or degree of an action
    • How fast did he run!?
  • Used with much and many to ask about quantity.
    • How much time did you put into this assignment?

Viewpoint and Commenting Adverbs

A very common practice in English is to put some of your own values into a sentence with an adverb. You can---subtly or not---express your viewpoint, opinion or comments on a topic. Such a commenting adverb can be placed in front of the sentence or at the end, separated by a comma. It can also be placed in front of the main verb, but that is somewhat unusual.

> Clearly, she doesn't know what she's talking about. (the writer's opinion is that she doesn't know what she's doing, and doesn't believe in her) > He undoubtedly has prepared accordingly. (the writer isn't sure, but his opinion is that he is a good fellow that always prepares himself well) > They are the ones to blame, obviously. (the writer is really sure about who is to blame, and therefore states that it's obvious, even though it might not be obvious at all)

List of Common Adverbs

Adverbs of Place

The most common ones are here (something close by) and there (something far away). Those are usually placed at the end of the sentence or after prepositions, but can be put at the front in sentence with exclamations or emphasis needed. In the pronouns chapter we also already discussed the important everywhere, anywhere, somewhere and nowhere.

But, there's also a list of words that function as an adverb as well as preposition (it never works the other way around: prepositions are not adverbs).

Word

Used as adverb of place

Used as preposition

around

He came around very often those days.

It was placed around the hearth.

behind

He was falling behind the others.

He hid behind the rocks.

down

He fell down.

She ran down the road.

in

He decided to jump in to save the situation.

The postman dropped letters in the mailbox.

off

I want to get off at the next stop.

He fell off the balcony.

on

They cycled on for a few more hours.

She placed all her books on the table.

over

She turned over twice before falling asleep.

The picture still hangs over my bed.

Adverbs of Time

There are three types of adverbs of time: how long, how often and when (exactly). If you use multiple, they should always be in that order. Time follows place in a sentence (unless you intend to emphasize one of them).

When: yesterday, tomorrow, today, later, now, last year, next year, …

How often: all day, for weeks, for years, since Tuesday, …

How long: often, never, always, seldom, rarely, frequently, regularly, usually, once a week, monthly, …

The word yet is used in questions and negative sentences if something hasn't happened or may not have happened, but is expected to happen.

> Have you finished working on that project yet?

The word still expresses continuity, mostly used in positive sentences. It is placed before the main verb, and after it if it is an auxiliary verb.

> He is still in love with you.
Adverbs of Manner

If a verb has an object (direct or indirect), the adverb needs to be placed in front of it or at the end of the clause. If not, it's best to put the adverb right behind.

Why? Because sometimes a sentence contains multiple verbs, and placing the adverb at the end of a sentence/away from its corresponding verb applies it to the whole clause, which you may not always want.

Adverbs of manner tell how something happened, for example: well, quickly, patiently, greedily, softly, beautifully, angrily, roughly, …

The adverbs of manner well, badly, hard and fast almost always come immediately after its verb.

Adverbs of Degree

Tell us about the intensity or degree of an action, usually placed directly before whatever they are modifying.

The adverb enough comes after what it modifies, and means something like "to the necessary degree". This can also express a quantity; as much/many as necessary. Often followed by for someone, for something or "to"+infinitive.

> He didn't do enough to pass the exam. But it was enough for me. Now I have enough points to get my diploma.

The adverb too has the same properties, and can have two meanings:

  • "Also": in this case, it is placed at the end of the sentence
    • I like swimming too!
  • "excessively": in this case, it comes before what it modifies
    • Am I too fat?

The adverb very makes an adverb or adjective stronger. In contrast to too, it simply states a fact, while too says there is a problem (things have gone too far). Not very can be used as a kind way to create a negative sentence.

> It was very bad => It wasn't very good
Adverbs of Certainty

Express how certain we feel about an event or action. Always go before the main verb, unless that verb is some form of to be. These are: certainly, definitely, probably, undoubtedly, surely

> She probably has some tricks up her sleeve. She is definitely a trickster. " slug: "english-adverbs" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 3 quiz: "" - id: 139 title: "[English] Determiners" post: "

All that's left to learn now, is a few simple but crucial words. I could have spread them all throughout the course, but I think that would have made it too messy and confusing, so that's why I'm presenting it as one group here.

> Determiners are placed in front of a noun to make clear what it refers to > Examples: my hat, these people, a few birds, ten children, other options

Determiners have 9 subcategories. But luckily, 4 of them have already been discussed:

  • Definite article: the
  • Indefinite article: a, an
  • Possessive determiners: my, your, his, her, its, our, their
  • Quantifiers: a few, a little, much, many, most, some, any, enough, a lot of

The others each have their own section with some explanation

Demonstratives

Demonstratives are used to show how nearby or close a noun we're referring to is. They are placed before the noun, or on their own if the noun itself is understood from the context.

Close by ("here")

Far away ("there")

Singular & Uncountable

This

That

Plural

These

Those

They can be used to show placement or position of things, but also as a way of referring back to things mentioned earlier (in the sentence or paragraph). In those cases you also follow the close by/far away rules.

> I like birds very much. It's this obsession that keeps me awake at night. (the obsession is of the speaker himself, so very close to him.) > He is more into lions. That's no problem, they are cool too. (his obsession is away from the speaker.)

Use this if you could hold something up in your hand, and that if you would point to it. With abstract things, you can do neither, and it's up to you to find out what sounds best.

Try to (mentally) substitute this/that with this here or that here, and you will often find what is the obvious choice.

Numbers

Numbers are placed in front of the noun, and the noun of course has to be put into plural form if the number is higher than one. The integers 0-10 are:

> Zero, One, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven, Eight, Nine, Ten

The ranking numbers (that show the rank of a noun in a certain order) are formed number + th. The first three ranking numbers are irregular, and are first, second and third.

> Seven => Seventh. Ten => Tenth. Twenty => Twentieth

When talking about numbers that are not integers but fractions we use the form numerator + ranking form denominator. Ranking numbers ending in ---th get an extra ---s.

> 1/3 => One Third. 4/5 => Four Fifths

Going one step further, we get to the decimal numbers, which use the construction "point" + every number behind the dot written individually.

> 0.6632 => point six six three two

And lastly, there are four ways to say 0:

  • Zero: if it's within a number
  • O: when reading years, addresses, times and temperatures
  • Nil: when reporting sports scores
  • Nought: used sparingly, for example when the zero is a subscript in a mathematical equation. Not used in the USA.

Distributives

Distributives, as the name suggests, distribute a noun among a group. There are four different types:

  • Each and every: to talk about members of a group as individuals
    • Each of them wanted a piece of cake.
  • All: to talk about the group as a whole
    • All members thought a reorganization of the company was necessary.
  • Half: to talk about a divided group
    • Half of the citizens were against the proposal.
  • Both, either and neither: to talk about pairs of people/things
    • Both parties agreed on the contract. Neither one wanted to hurt the other's feelings.

Difference Words

Difference words refer to something different, remaining or additional. There's only two of them:

  • Other: for plural countable and uncountable nouns, and any noun that takes the.
    • I saw him the other day. Other people saw him as well. Did others see him?
  • Another: singular (countable) nouns.
    • Another week went by with another attack.

Pre-Determiners

Pre-determiners are placed before an indefinite article (a/an) + adjective + noun to express an opinion about the noun they modify. These are:

  • Such and what: to express surprise or other emotions.
    • What a lovely dress! We've had such a good time in the cinema.
  • Rather and quite: to refer to the degree the adjective modifies the noun. It depends on the adjective whether they bring positive or negative emotions.
    • That's quite a lovely dress. I've had a rather good time in the cinema.

" slug: "english-determiners" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 3 quiz: "" - id: 140 title: "[English] Cheat Sheet" post: "

You can use the image below to quickly remind yourself of the basic grammar rules in case you are in doubt. I present, the English Grammar Cheat Sheet!

" slug: "english-grammar-cheat-sheet" cat: "Writing" subcat: "English" video: "" diff: 3 quiz: "" - id: 141 title: "Words & Phrases to Avoid" post: "

Most writers are lazy. They use vague language to get the job done, where a definite statement would make the writing shorter and clearer. This article isn't so much about correcting bad English as improving your style. Many expressions mentioned here are grammatically correct, and even very popular, but should be restricted to colloquialisms. The book Elements of Style---which I highly recommend---has been the inspiration for this article.

An Alphabetic List

Absolutely

Often redundant when used to emphasize adjectives. Either someone is honest, or he isn't. Absolutely honest doesn't make him more honest.

All right

Alright has become more popular, but two separate words is still the correct form. Used in familiar speech in the sense of "Agreed" or "Go ahead". Avoid using it for anything else.

Always

Unless you're giving written commands or instruction, find another word. Always is rarely true, and opens the door to criticism regarding inaccuracies.

Amazing

Overused. Omit it, or at least find a more fitting synonym. If everything is amazing, nothing is.

As good or better

Rearrange the sentence so that "or better" (or "if not better") is at the end

> This is as good or better than that => This is as good as that, or better

As to whether

Just whether is sufficient.

Bid

Takes the infinitive without to. The past tense is bade.

> I bade him to do it => I bade him do it.

Case

When used in the senses instance of a thing's occurring or usual state of affairs, it's usually unnecessary.

> In many cases, the houses had been destroyed => Many houses had been destroyed.

Certainly

Used too often to intensify any and every statement. Don't.

Character

Often redundant and used out of habit only.

> Acts of a hostile character => Hostile acts

Claim

With object, means lay claim to. Not to be used as a substitute for declare, maintain or charge.

Compare

The preposition that accompanies it makes the difference.

> To compare to is to point out or imply resemblances between objects regarded as different > To compare with is to point out differences between objects regarded as similar

Clever

Greatly overused. Best restricted to ingenuity displayed in small matters.

Consider

When followed by "as" means "believe to be". Otherwise means "examined" or "discussed".

Dependable

A needless substitute for reliable or trustworthy.

Due to

Correctly used when related to a particular noun as predicate or modifier.

> Losses due to bad policy

Incorrectly used for through, because of or owing to in adverbial phrases:

> She lost the game, due to carelessness

Effect

As noun, means result. As verb, means to bring about or accomplish. Should not be confused with affect, which means "to influence".

Too often used as a vague substitute in writing about any sort of art ("the painter used very delicate effects"), which is bad.

Etc.

Equivalent to and the rest or and so forth. Should therefore not be used of persons, or if the reader could be left in doubt as to any important particulars. Best used to shorten a list which has already been given in full, or to replace unimportant words at the end of a quotation.

Ending lists starting with expressions like such as or for example with "etc." is incorrect.

Fact

Use this only of actual facts, matters capable of direct verification, and never for matters of judgment, however incontestable they may be.

Factor

Overused. Can often be replaced by something more direct or definite.

> Superior preparation was the biggest factor in his winning => He won by being prepared better

Feature

Like factor, it usually adds nothing to a sentence.

To be avoided in the advertising sense of offer as a special attraction.

Fix

Colloquial (in American English) for arrange, prepare or mend. Restrict it to its literary senses; fasten, make firm or immovable, etc.

He is a man who

A common type of redundant expression, with some variations;

> England is a country which I like => I like England. > He is a man who likes to play games => He likes to play games

Honestly

Often used to add emphasis, but should be avoided, for it implies that the rest of your statements wasn't honest.

However

Comes first in the sentence when it means "in whatever way" or "to whatever extent".

> However hard you try, it won't happen.

Not to come first when it means "nevertheless".

> I feel sorry for him. It is, however, not my problem.

Irregardless

It's not a word. Regardless already means without regard.

Just

Unless you're using it with the meaning of equitable, fair, even-handed or impartial, don't use it at all. Often has no meaning and makes your sentences weaker.

Kind of

Don't use it as substitute for rather (before adjectives and verbs) or something like (before nouns). Restrict it to its literal sense;

> He plays guitar with a strange kind of passion.

The same is true for sort of.

Less

Don't misuse it for fewer. Less refers to quantity (or "size"), fewer to number.

> His troubles are less than mine = he has smaller troubles > His troubles are fewer than mine = he doesn't have as many troubles as I do

An exception are round numbers, which are regarded as a collective noun.

Line

Can be used in the sense of course of procedure, conduct or thought, but has been overdone so much (especially with the phrase along these lines), that you better avoid it.

Literally

Too often incorrectly used in support of exaggeration or violent metaphor, or when the writer actually means figuratively.

> He was literally dead with fatigue => He was almost dead with fatigue

Lose out

Used to sound more emphatic than lose, but doesn't work. The same holds for try out, win out, sign up and register up.

A number of verbs form combinations with out and up, with different meanings---but lose out does not.

Maybe

Communicates uncertainty. Unless you are posing a question, be sure of what you write and create informed pieces.

Nature

Often redundant, just like character. Sentences can usually be shortened, or more specific statements need to follow to explain one another.

> Acts of a hostile nature => Hostile acts

Near by

Analogous with close by and hard by, but is usually written as one word; nearby. Near (at hand), however, is as good, if not better.

Not to be used as an adjective; use neighbouring instead.

Never

See: "always".

Oftentimes

Archaic, use often.

One hundred and one

Retain the "and" in this and similar expressions.

One of the most

Avoid beginning paragraphs with this kind of formula;

> The guitar is one of the most universally played instruments, …

It's not wrong, and even sounds good, but it's cliché, vague and meaningless.

People

The people is a political term; they create political support or opposition. Don't confuse it with the public, from whom comes artistic appreciation or commercial support.

Don't use people with after number words when persons can be used.

Phase

Means stage of transition or development, not aspect or topic.

Possess

Don't use it as a mere substitute for the simpler verbs have or own.

Really

Just as "very", don't use it to modify an adjective, verb or adverb.

Respectively

May usually be omitted, often improving sentence clarity.

> The books are listed under the names of their respective authors > The books are listed under the names of their authors

In some kinds of formal writing (such as geometrical proofs) it may be necessary, but it shouldn't appear in writing otherwise.

So

Avoid using it as an intensifier (so good).

To state

Don't use it as a mere substitute for say or remark. Restrict it to the sense of express fully or clearly.

Student body

A needless expression, just students is enough.

Stuff

Casual and generic. A placeholder for when the writer doesn't know the actual word or phrase. If you don't bother finding out or explaining the details, don't reference something at all.

System

Frequently used without necessity.

> They have adopted the commission system of government > They have adopted government by commission.

That

Superfluous most of the time. Reread every sentence with that and see if you can leave it out.

> He saw that the bird was eating => He saw the bird was eating

Don't use it with people, the proper word is who.

They

Often incorrectly used with distributive expressions, such as each or everybody. Although they imply more than one person, they are regarded as singular.

Use he instead, unless the antecedent is or must be feminine.

Things

See: "stuff".

Very

Use sparingly to exaggerate nouns. If emphasis is necessary, find a strong word.

> Very tired => Morose > Very happy => Ecstatic

Viewpoint

Write point of view, and don't use it for view or opinion.

Went

Don't use went for every action in your story. Consider more definite statements such as walked, ran, drove, cycled.

While

Avoid using it in place of "and" or "but". Instead, use a semicolon.

Using it for "although" is only allowable where this leads to no ambiguity or absurdity.

It's best to restrict while to the sense of during the time that.

Whom

Is used when it's the direct or indirect object. Often incorrectly used for who before he said or similar expressions.

Worth while

Overworked for vague (dis)approval. Restrict it to only actions.

> Is it worth while to phone him?

Using it before a noun (a worth while visit to the zoo) is terrible.

Would

A conditional statement in the first person requires should, not would.

> I should have died if he hadn't saved me.

The equivalent of shall in indirect quotation after a verb in past tense is should, not would.

> He said that soon enough the earth should be hit by an asteroid.

To express habitual or repeated action, the past tense (without would) is usually sufficient.

> Once a year he would visit his grandmother > Once a year he visited his grandmother " slug: "english-words-phrases-misused-avoid" cat: "Writing" subcat: "" video: "" diff: 1 quiz: "" - id: 142 title: "[HTML5 Entities] A" post: "

ю yucy 0044E
Ÿ Yuml 00178
ÿ yuml 000FF
